11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-010-9400-z940010.1007/s11243-010-9400-zArticleCopper(II) coordination frameworks with 1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylic acid: syntheses, crystal structures and magnetic propertiesWangKunmiao1DuLin1HanJinmei1LiZongze1XieMingjin1ZhaoQihua1fgrid.440773.3Department of Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry for Natural Resource, Ministry of EducationYunnan University650091KunmingChina+86-871-5032929+86-871-5032929qhzhao@ynu.edu.cn297201010201035782983497201016520108720102972010© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20102010Abstract

Cu(II) polymers of Hbidc (1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate), namely [Cu2(Hbidc)2(H2O)4·3H2O]n (1) and [Cu(Hbidc)]n (2), were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by variation of the reaction temperature and characterized by physico-chemical, spectroscopic and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. At temperatures from 100 to 170 °C, we only obtained the 2-D structure compounds 1 and 2, in which the bridging mode of the Hbidc ligand increases from μ3 to μ5 and the number of water ligands decreases to 0. Both compounds have 3-D supramolecular architectures extended by hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions between the adjacent layers. Magnetic studies revealed that compound 1 shows weak antiferromagnetic properties and compound 2 exhibits ferromagnetic coupling between the two Cu(II) ions in the dimeric units.

Introduction

Crystal engineering of coordination polymers has attracted much interest in recent years because of their potential applications arising from their variable architectures [1–4]. Although in the assembly process of coordination polymers, the coordination properties of the metal ion or metal clusters, as well as the organic ligands, often play a leading role in the structure, there are many factors that can influence the formation of coordination polymers [5]. Crystallographic studies have shown that the reaction temperature as well as crystallization conditions, pH value, solvent, etc. all play an important role in the regulation of the structure [6]. Encouraged by the previous literature, in this paper, we have investigated the effect of temperature as the reaction of 1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate (H3bidc) with copper(II). In the previously reported H3bidc-metal coordination polymers, a variety of coordination modes, including κ2O:O′; μ2-κ3O:O′,O″; μ3-κ3N,O,O′; syn-anti-μ3-κ4N,O,O′:O″; syn-syn-μ3-κ4N,O:O′,O′; μ4-κ6N,O:O′, O′:O″,O″; μ4-κ5N,O,O′:O″,O″ [7–9], attracted our attention. We considered that the ligand coordination mode should be relatively easy to be change by the reaction conditions. Herein, we report two coordination polymers prepared by temperature-controlled conditions from the same reaction system, namely H3bidc-Cu(NO3)3, and the highest coordination mode (μ5-κ5N, O, O, O′,O″) exhibited by H3bidc to date.

Experimental

All the materials and reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were determined using an Elemental Vario EL elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000–400 cm−1 region. Thermogravimetric experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 750 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument in the 2θ range 5–50° using Cu Kα radiation at room temperature. Variable-temperature (2.0–300.0 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS60000 instrument in a magnetic field of 1,000 Oe.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>2</sub>(Hbidc)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture Cu(NO3)2·2H2O (0.072 g, 0.3 mmol) and H3bidc (0.062 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (8 mL) and stirred for about 1 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was sealed in a stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting lime green crystals were washed with water and acetonitrile to give complex 1 (62 mg, 87% yield based on Cu). Crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and dried in air. Found: C, 32.8; H, 3.4; N, 8.5. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C9H11CuN2O7.5: C, 32.7; H, 3.4; N 8.5. IR (KBr, pellet/cm−1): 3,450, 3,315, 3,152, 1,562, 1,520, 1,480, 1,417, 1,368, 1,260, 1,181, 1,046, 874, 794, 703.

Preparation of [Cu(Hbidc)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was prepared by the same procedure for 1 except that the reaction temperature was 160 °C. For 2, C9H4CuN2O4, 46 mg, yield: 53% (based on Cu). Found: C, 40.5; H, 1.6; N, 10.5. Anal. Calcd. (%): C, 40.4; H, 1.5; N 10.5. IR (KBr, pellet/cm−1): 3,345, 3,142, 1,637, 1,549, 1,477, 1,415, 1,307, 1,252, 1,184, 1,039, 966, 886, 797, 635.

X-ray crystallography

Single-crystal data of complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II diffractometer with using graphite-monochromatic MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADBAS program [10]. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F2 using full-matrix least-squares procedures with anisotropic displacement parameters. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, whereas the hydrogen atoms of the organic molecules were placed using geometrical considerations and were added to the structure factor calculation (C–H bonds fixed at 0.97 and 0.93 Å). All calculations were performed using the SHELXS-97 crystallographic soft package. [11] Crystallographic data and processing parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table 1.

Results and discussion

Reaction of copper(II) nitrate with H3bidc at lower reaction temperatures (100–130 °C) only produced complex 1, while higher reaction temperatures (150–170 °C) always formed compound 2. At other reaction temperatures, we only got green powders or amorphous substances. Using the same proportions of reactants, we tried to change the solvent (water; water/acetonitrile; methanol; etc.) and re-adjust the reaction temperature; however, we only obtained compound 2 at high temperature. The synthesis of such coordination polymers by self-assembly processes is greatly complex and non-controllable, but we hope that the successful synthesis of these compounds will be helpful in future studies (Table 2).

Structural characterization of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The crystallographically independent Cu(II) atom at the inversion center possesses octahedral geometry, provided by three carboxylate oxygen atoms, two aqua oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom, in which the aqua oxygen atoms occupy the apical positions and the other four atoms are in the equatorial plane. The distances of the Cu–Ochelated bonds (O1 and O2) are slightly longer than the other Cu–O distances. Each bidc2− unit binds three Cu atoms through a μ3-κ2O, O′, O″, N coordination fashion forming two kinds of rings; the first including two Cu(II) atoms and the second including four Cu(II) atoms (Fig. 1). The Cu···Cu distance in the first type of ring is 8.258(9) Å which is much longer than the shorter Cu···Cu distance (5.382 Å) but shorter than the longest Cu···Cu distance (9.778(3) Å) in the second type of ring. Topologically, each Cu(II) atom and bidc2− ligand act as 3-connecting nodes, to generate a non-interpenetrated (6, 3) network (Fig. 2). In the same layer, weak π–π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of bidc2− ligands were identified with the shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg···Cg of 3.734(2) Å. In the packing arrangement of 1, the adjacent 2-D supramolecular layers are parallel with each other and construct a 3-D supramolecular framework via hydrogen bonding. There are two kinds of hydrogen bonding, namely N–H···O (the shortest distance 2.907 Å (127°) and O–H···O (the shortest distance 2.13 Å (158°).

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complex 2 also revealed an extended 2-D coordination network that crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group Pī. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of only one copper center and one Hbidc2− ligand; no aqua ligands were present in compound 2. The Cu(II) center coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms of four separate Hbidc2− ligands (the average Cu–O distance is 2.086 Å) and one imidazole nitrogen atom (Cu–N distance is 1.969(4) Å) to furnish a distorted trigonal bipyramid environment (Fig. 1). A couple of inversely related copper atoms are bridged by two μ2-κ2O, O′ and two μ2-κ2O, O carboxylate groups (Cu–O–Cu angle 80.12(1)°) into a paddle-wheel dimer with an intradimer Cu···Cu distance of 2.821(8) Å. The Cu dimers in 2 are connected via the benzimidazole framework to give a staggered ring structure. In this structure, each bidc2− ligand exhibits μ5-κ5N, O, O, O′, O″ multidentate coordination, linking five copper atoms into an infinite two-dimensional layer. The dimers act as 4-connected nodes linked via Hbidc2− ligands to give a (4, 4) coordinated network (Fig. 2). The weak π–π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of Hbidc2− ligands give a shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg···Cg of 4.119(3) Å (0.02°). There is only one type of hydrogen bonding, involving N–H···O (N···O distance 2.860 Å and N–H···O angle 174.39°) which connects the layers into a three-dimensional architecture.

Spectroscopic and physical properties

In the IR spectrum of compound 1, a strong and broad peak at around 3,400 cm−1 is attributed to water. There are no absorptions between 1,730 and 1,700 cm−1, indicating that the carboxylate groups of H3bidc are completely deprotonated. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the completely deprotonated carboxylate groups are observed at about 1,550 and 1,410 cm−1, and at 1,310 cm−1, respectively, showing that the carboxylate groups adopt the chelating and monodentate coordination geometry [12, 13]. A sharp band at about 3,300 cm−1 for both 1 and 2 is attributed to N–H stretching vibrations [14].

Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on both complexes in air, with heating to 780 °C at a rate of 1 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different thermal behaviors, but the TG curve of 2 is similar to that of 1 (from 228 to 780 °C, Fig. 3). In 1, the TGA displays two obvious steps of weight loss. The first corresponds to the loss of both lattice and coordinated water (at the range of 85–264 °C, the weight loss observed is 19.16%; theoretical 19.04%). The second weight loss above 250 °C is attributable to decomposition of the organic ligand. The TGA of compound 2 demonstrates that compound 2 has an excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 250 °C.

The magnetic behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 are illustrated in Fig. 4 in the form of μeff versus T plots. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.72 μB for compound 1, which is as expected for the spin-only value of 1.73 μB for one Cu(II) atom. Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu···Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu–O–Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu–O–Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu–O–Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu···Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.

Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized two 2-D Cu(II) coordination polymers by controlling the temperature (1 at 100 °C and 2 at 160 °C) of hydrothermal conditions and using Hbidc2− as a bridging ligand. These two polymeric structures possess different properties. Compound 2 exhibits a higher thermal stability than compound 1 due to the water-free 2-D polymeric network. The short distance between Cu(II) atoms and small Cu–O–Cu angle in the dimer may lead to ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Cu(II) atoms in 2, while the long Cu···Cu distance may result in the antiferromagnetic character of compound 1. H3bidc has a great potential in the field of coordination polymers and further endeavors for study the similar ligands are under way in our laboratory.

A sharp band at about 3,300 cm-1 for both 1 and 2 is attributed to N-H stretching vibrations [14].Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on both complexes in air, with heating to 780 °C at a rate of 1 °C min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different thermal behaviors, but the TG curve of 2 is similar to that of 1 (from 228 to 780 °C, Fig. 3). In 1, the TGA displays two obvious steps of weight loss. The first corresponds to the loss of both lattice and coordinated water (at the range of 85-264 °C, the weight loss observed is 19.16%; theoretical 19.04%). The second weight loss above 250 °C is attributable to decomposition of the organic ligand. The TGA of compound 2 demonstrates that compound 2 has an excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 250 °C.The magnetic behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 are illustrated in Fig. 4 in the form of μeff versus T plots. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.72 μB for compound 1, which is as expected for the spin-only value of 1.73 μB for one Cu(II) atom. Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu-O-Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu-O-Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu-O-Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.ConclusionIn summary, we have synthesized two 2-D Cu(II) coordination polymers by controlling the temperature (1 at 100 °C and 2 at 160 °C) of hydrothermal conditions and using Hbidc2- as a bridging ligand. These two polymeric structures possess different properties. Compound 2 exhibits a higher thermal stability than compound 1 due to the water-free 2-D polymeric network. The short distance between Cu(II) atoms and small Cu-O-Cu angle in the dimer may lead to ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Cu(II) atoms in 2, while the long Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance may result in the antiferromagnetic character of compound 1. H3bidc has a great potential in the field of coordination polymers and further endeavors for study the similar ligands are under way in our laboratory.AcknowledgmentsThis work was supported by the National Nature Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 20761005), the Key Project of Chinese Ministry of Education (No: 205147).References1.RobsonRJ Chem Soc Dalton Trans200021373510.1039/b003591m2.JaniakCDalton Trans200314278110.1039/b305705b3.FéreyGChem Soc Rev20083719110.1039/b618320b4.SuhM-PCheonYELeeEYCoord Chem Rev200825210071:CAS:528:DC%2BD1cXkvVGgtLs%3D10.1016/j.ccr.2008.01.0325.Lehn JM (1995) Supramolecular chemistry, concepts and perspectives. elements.content: Cu(II) polymers of Hbidc (1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate), namely [Cu2(Hbidc)2(H2O)4·3H2O]n (1) and [Cu(Hbidc)]n (2), were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by variation of the reaction temperature and characterized by physico-chemical, spectroscopic and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. At temperatures from 100 to 170 °C, we only obtained the 2-D structure compounds 1 and 2, in which the bridging mode of the Hbidc ligand increases from μ3 to μ5 and the number of water ligands decreases to 0. Both compounds have 3-D supramolecular architectures extended by hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions between the adjacent layers. Magnetic studies revealed that compound 1 shows weak antiferromagnetic properties and compound 2 exhibits ferromagnetic coupling between the two Cu(II) ions in the dimeric units.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Cu(II) polymers of Hbidc (1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate), namely [Cu2(Hbidc)2(H2O)4⋅3H2O]n (1) and [Cu(Hbidc)]n (2), were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions by variation of the reaction temperature and characterized by physico-chemical, spectroscopic and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. At temperatures from 100 to 170 °C, we only obtained the 2-D structure compounds 1 and 2, in which the bridging mode of the Hbidc ligand increases from μ3 to μ5 and the number of water ligands decreases to 0. Both compounds have 3-D supramolecular architectures extended by hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions between the adjacent layers. Magnetic studies revealed that compound 1 shows weak antiferromagnetic properties and compound 2 exhibits ferromagnetic coupling between the two Cu(II) ions in the dimeric units.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of coordination polymers has attracted much interest in recent years because of their potential applications arising from their variable architectures [1–4]. Although in the assembly process of coordination polymers, the coordination properties of the metal ion or metal clusters, as well as the organic ligands, often play a leading role in the structure, there are many factors that can influence the formation of coordination polymers [5]. Crystallographic studies have shown that the reaction temperature as well as crystallization conditions, pH value, solvent, etc. all play an important role in the regulation of the structure [6]. Encouraged by the previous literature, in this paper, we have investigated the effect of temperature as the reaction of 1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate (H3bidc) with copper(II). In the previously reported H3bidc-metal coordination polymers, a variety of coordination modes, including κ2O:O′; μ2-κ3O:O′,O″; μ3-κ3N,O,O′; syn-anti-μ3-κ4N,O,O′:O″; syn-syn-μ3-κ4N,O:O′,O′; μ4-κ6N,O:O′, O′:O″,O″; μ4-κ5N,O,O′:O″,O″ [7–9], attracted our attention. We considered that the ligand coordination mode should be relatively easy to be change by the reaction conditions. Herein, we report two coordination polymers prepared by temperature-controlled conditions from the same reaction system, namely H3bidc-Cu(NO3)3, and the highest coordination mode (μ5-κ5N, O, O, O′,O″) exhibited by H3bidc to date.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of coordination polymers has attracted much interest in recent years because of their potential applications arising from their variable architectures [1-4]. Although in the assembly process of coordination polymers, the coordination properties of the metal ion or metal clusters, as well as the organic ligands, often play a leading role in the structure, there are many factors that can influence the formation of coordination polymers [5]. Crystallographic studies have shown that the reaction temperature as well as crystallization conditions, pH value, solvent, etc. all play an important role in the regulation of the structure [6]. Encouraged by the previous literature, in this paper, we have investigated the effect of temperature as the reaction of 1H-benzimidazole-5,6-dicarboxylate (H3bidc) with copper(II). In the previously reported H3bidc-metal coordination polymers, a variety of coordination modes, including κ2O:O'; μ2-κ3O:O',O"; μ3-κ3N,O,O'; syn-anti-μ3-κ4N,O,O':O"; syn-syn-μ3-κ4N,O:O',O'; μ4-κ6N,O:O', O':O",O"; μ4-κ5N,O,O':O",O" [7-9], attracted our attention. We considered that the ligand coordination mode should be relatively easy to be change by the reaction conditions. Herein, we report two coordination polymers prepared by temperature-controlled conditions from the same reaction system, namely H3bidc-Cu(NO3)3, and the highest coordination mode (μ5-κ5N, O, O, O',O") exhibited by H3bidc to date.

elements.content: All the materials and reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were determined using an Elemental Vario EL elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000–400 cm−1 region. Thermogravimetric experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 750 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument in the 2θ range 5–50° using Cu Kα radiation at room temperature. Variable-temperature (2.0–300.0 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS60000 instrument in a magnetic field of 1,000 Oe.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All the materials and reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were determined using an Elemental Vario EL elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750FT-IR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4,000-400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 750 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument in the 2θ range 5-50° using Cu Kα radiation at room temperature. Variable-temperature (2.0-300.0 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS60000 instrument in a magnetic field of 1,000 Oe.

elements.content: A mixture Cu(NO3)2·2H2O (0.072 g, 0.3 mmol) and H3bidc (0.062 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (8 mL) and stirred for about 1 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was sealed in a stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting lime green crystals were washed with water and acetonitrile to give complex 1 (62 mg, 87% yield based on Cu). Crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and dried in air. Found: C, 32.8; H, 3.4; N, 8.5. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C9H11CuN2O7.5: C, 32.7; H, 3.4; N 8.5. The resulting solution was sealed in a stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, then slowly cooled to room temperature. elements.content: Single-crystal data of complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II diffractometer with using graphite-monochromatic MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADBAS program [10]. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F2 using full-matrix least-squares procedures with anisotropic displacement parameters. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, whereas the hydrogen atoms of the organic molecules were placed using geometrical considerations and were added to the structure factor calculation (C–H bonds fixed at 0.97 and 0.93 Å). All calculations were performed using the SHELXS-97 crystallographic soft package. [11] Crystallographic data and processing parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single-crystal data of complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX-II diffractometer with using graphite-monochromatic MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the SADBAS program [10]. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F2 using full-matrix least-squares procedures with anisotropic displacement parameters. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters, whereas the hydrogen atoms of the organic molecules were placed using geometrical considerations and were added to the structure factor calculation (C-H bonds fixed at 0.97 and 0.93 Å). All calculations were performed using the SHELXS-97 crystallographic soft package. [11] Crystallographic data and processing parameters for compounds 1 and 2 are listed in Table 1.

Reaction of copper(II) nitrate with H3bidc at lower reaction temperatures (100–130 °C) only produced complex 1, while higher reaction temperatures (150–170 °C) always formed compound 2. At other reaction temperatures, we only got green powders or amorphous substances. Using the same proportions of reactants, we tried to change the solvent (water; water/acetonitrile; methanol; etc.) and re-adjust the reaction temperature; however, we only obtained compound 2 at high temperature. The synthesis of such coordination polymers by self-assembly processes is greatly complex and non-controllable, but we hope that the successful synthesis of these compounds will be helpful in future studies (Table 2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Reaction of copper(II) nitrate with H3bidc at lower reaction temperatures (100-130 °C) only produced complex 1, while higher reaction temperatures (150-170 °C) always formed compound 2. At other reaction temperatures, we only got green powders or amorphous substances. Using the same proportions of reactants, we tried to change the solvent (water; water/acetonitrile; methanol; etc.) and re-adjust the reaction temperature; however, we only obtained compound 2 at high temperature. The synthesis of such coordination polymers by self-assembly processes is greatly complex and non-controllable, but we hope that the successful synthesis of these compounds will be helpful in future studies (Table 2).

Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The crystallographically independent Cu(II) atom at the inversion center possesses octahedral geometry, provided by three carboxylate oxygen atoms, two aqua oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom, in which the aqua oxygen atoms occupy the apical positions and the other four atoms are in the equatorial plane. The distances of the Cu–Ochelated bonds (O1 and O2) are slightly longer than the other Cu–O distances. Each bidc2− unit binds three Cu atoms through a μ3-κ2O, O′, O″, N coordination fashion forming two kinds of rings; the first including two Cu(II) atoms and the second including four Cu(II) atoms (Fig. 1). The Cu···Cu distance in the first type of ring is 8.258(9) Å which is much longer than the shorter Cu···Cu distance (5.382 Å) but shorter than the longest Cu···Cu distance (9.778(3) Å) in the second type of ring. Topologically, each Cu(II) atom and bidc2− ligand act as 3-connecting nodes, to generate a non-interpenetrated (6, 3) network (Fig. 2). In the same layer, weak π–π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of bidc2− ligands were identified with the shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg···Cg of 3.734(2) Å. In the packing arrangement of 1, the adjacent 2-D supramolecular layers are parallel with each other and construct a 3-D supramolecular framework via hydrogen bonding. There are two kinds of hydrogen bonding, namely N–H···O (the shortest distance 2.907 Å (127°) and O–H···O (the shortest distance 2.13 Å (158°).
elements.clean_text:
Structural characterization of 1 and 2

Compound 1 crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The crystallographically independent Cu(II) atom at the inversion center possesses octahedral geometry, provided by three carboxylate oxygen atoms, two aqua oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom, in which the aqua oxygen atoms occupy the apical positions and the other four atoms are in the equatorial plane. The distances of the Cu-Ochelated bonds (O1 and O2) are slightly longer than the other Cu-O distances. Each bidc2- unit binds three Cu atoms through a μ3-κ2O, O', O", N coordination fashion forming two kinds of rings; the first including two Cu(II) atoms and the second including four Cu(II) atoms (Fig. 1). The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance in the first type of ring is 8.258(9) Å which is much longer than the shorter Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance (5.382 Å) but shorter than the longest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance (9.778(3) Å) in the second type of ring. Topologically, each Cu(II) atom and bidc2- ligand act as 3-connecting nodes, to generate a non-interpenetrated (6, 3) network (Fig. 2). In the same layer, weak π-π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of bidc2- ligands were identified with the shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg⋅⋅⋅Cg of 3.734(2) Å. In the packing arrangement of 1, the adjacent 2-D supramolecular layers are parallel with each other and construct a 3-D supramolecular framework via hydrogen bonding. There are two kinds of hydrogen bonding, namely N-H⋅⋅⋅O (the shortest distance 2.907 Å (127°) and O-H⋅⋅⋅O (the shortest distance 2.13 Å (158°).

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complex 2 also revealed an extended 2-D coordination network that crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group Pī. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of only one copper center and one Hbidc2− ligand; no aqua ligands were present in compound 2. The Cu(II) center coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms of four separate Hbidc2− ligands (the average Cu–O distance is 2.086 Å) and one imidazole nitrogen atom (Cu–N distance is 1.969(4) Å) to furnish a distorted trigonal bipyramid environment (Fig. 1). A couple of inversely related copper atoms are bridged by two μ2-κ2O, O′ and two μ2-κ2O, O carboxylate groups (Cu–O–Cu angle 80.12(1)°) into a paddle-wheel dimer with an intradimer Cu···Cu distance of 2.821(8) Å. The Cu dimers in 2 are connected via the benzimidazole framework to give a staggered ring structure. In this structure, each bidc2− ligand exhibits μ5-κ5N, O, O, O′, O″ multidentate coordination, linking five copper atoms into an infinite two-dimensional layer. The dimers act as 4-connected nodes linked via Hbidc2− ligands to give a (4, 4) coordinated network (Fig. 2). The weak π–π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of Hbidc2− ligands give a shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg···Cg of 4.119(3) Å (0.02°). There is only one type of hydrogen bonding, involving N–H···O (N···O distance 2.860 Å and N–H···O angle 174.39°) which connects the layers into a three-dimensional architecture.
elements.clean_text: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complex 2 also revealed an extended 2-D coordination network that crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group Pī. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of only one copper center and one Hbidc2- ligand; no aqua ligands were present in compound 2. The Cu(II) center coordinates to four carboxylate oxygen atoms of four separate Hbidc2- ligands (the average Cu-O distance is 2.086 Å) and one imidazole nitrogen atom (Cu-N distance is 1.969(4) Å) to furnish a distorted trigonal bipyramid environment (Fig. 1). A couple of inversely related copper atoms are bridged by two μ2-κ2O, O' and two μ2-κ2O, O carboxylate groups (Cu-O-Cu angle 80.12(1)°) into a paddle-wheel dimer with an intradimer Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.821(8) Å. The Cu dimers in 2 are connected via the benzimidazole framework to give a staggered ring structure. In this structure, each bidc2- ligand exhibits μ5-κ5N, O, O, O', O" multidentate coordination, linking five copper atoms into an infinite two-dimensional layer. The dimers act as 4-connected nodes linked via Hbidc2- ligands to give a (4, 4) coordinated network (Fig. 2). The weak π-π interactions between the benzimidazole groups of Hbidc2- ligands give a shortest distance between the ring centroids Cg⋅⋅⋅Cg of 4.119(3) Å (0.02°). There is only one type of hydrogen bonding, involving N-H⋅⋅⋅O (N⋅⋅⋅O distance 2.860 Å and N-H⋅⋅⋅O angle 174.39°) which connects the layers into a three-dimensional architecture.

elements.content: In the IR spectrum of compound 1, a strong and broad peak at around 3,400 cm−1 is attributed to water. There are no absorptions between 1,730 and 1,700 cm−1, indicating that the carboxylate groups of H3bidc are completely deprotonated. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the completely deprotonated carboxylate groups are observed at about 1,550 and 1,410 cm−1, and at 1,310 cm−1, respectively, showing that the carboxylate groups adopt the chelating and monodentate coordination geometry [12, 13]. A sharp band at about 3,300 cm−1 for both 1 and 2 is attributed to N–H stretching vibrations [14].
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic and physical properties

In the IR spectrum of compound 1, a strong and broad peak at around 3,400 cm-1 is attributed to water. There are no absorptions between 1,730 and 1,700 cm-1, indicating that the carboxylate groups of H3bidc are completely deprotonated. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the completely deprotonated carboxylate groups are observed at about 1,550 and 1,410 cm-1, and at 1,310 cm-1, respectively, showing that the carboxylate groups adopt the chelating and monodentate coordination geometry [12, 13]. A sharp band at about 3,300 cm-1 for both 1 and 2 is attributed to N-H stretching vibrations [14].

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on both complexes in air, with heating to 780 °C at a rate of 1 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different thermal behaviors, but the TG curve of 2 is similar to that of 1 (from 228 to 780 °C, Fig. 3). In 1, the TGA displays two obvious steps of weight loss. The first corresponds to the loss of both lattice and coordinated water (at the range of 85–264 °C, the weight loss observed is 19.16%; theoretical 19.04%). The second weight loss above 250 °C is attributable to decomposition of the organic ligand. The TGA of compound 2 demonstrates that compound 2 has an excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 250 °C.

elements.content: The magnetic behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 are illustrated in Fig. 4 in the form of μeff versus T plots. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.72 μB for compound 1, which is as expected for the spin-only value of 1.73 μB for one Cu(II) atom. Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu···Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu–O–Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu–O–Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu–O–Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu···Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.

Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu-O-Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu-O-Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu-O-Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized two 2-D Cu(II) coordination polymers by controlling the temperature (1 at 100 °C and 2 at 160 °C) of hydrothermal conditions and using Hbidc2− as a bridging ligand. These two polymeric structures possess different properties. Compound 2 exhibits a higher thermal stability than compound 1 due to the water-free 2-D polymeric network. The short distance between Cu(II) atoms and small Cu–O–Cu angle in the dimer may lead to ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Cu(II) atoms in 2, while the long Cu···Cu distance may result in the antiferromagnetic character of compound 1. H3bidc has a great potential in the field of coordination polymers and further endeavors for study the similar ligands are under way in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized two 2-D Cu(II) coordination polymers by controlling the temperature (1 at 100 °C and 2 at 160 °C) of hydrothermal conditions and using Hbidc2- as a bridging ligand. These two polymeric structures possess different properties. Compound 2 exhibits a higher thermal stability than compound 1 due to the water-free 2-D polymeric network. The short distance between Cu(II) atoms and small Cu-O-Cu angle in the dimer may lead to ferromagnetic coupling between pairs of Cu(II) atoms in 2, while the long Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance may result in the antiferromagnetic character of compound 1. H3bidc has a great potential in the field of coordination polymers and further endeavors for study the similar ligands are under way in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture Cu(NO3)2·2H2O (0.072 g, 0.3 mmol) and H3bidc (0.062 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (8 mL) and stirred for about 1 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was sealed in a stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting lime green crystals were washed with water and acetonitrile to give complex 1 (62 mg, 87% yield based on Cu). Crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and dried in air. Found: C, 32.8; H, 3.4; N, 8.5. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C9H11CuN2O7.5: C, 32.7; H, 3.4; N 8.5. IR (KBr, pellet/cm−1): 3,450, 3,315, 3,152, 1,562, 1,520, 1,480, 1,417, 1,368, 1,260, 1,181, 1,046, 874, 794, 703.

Preparation of [Cu(Hbidc)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was prepared by the same procedure for 1 except that the reaction temperature was 160 °C. For 2, C9H4CuN2O4, 46 mg, yield: 53% (based on Cu). Found: C, 40.5; H, 1.6; N, 10.5. Anal. Calcd. (%): C, 40.4; H, 1.5; N 10.5. IR (KBr, pellet/cm−1): 3,345, 3,142, 1,637, 1,549, 1,477, 1,415, 1,307, 1,252, 1,184, 1,039, 966, 886, 797, 635.

A mixture Cu(NO3)2⋅2H2O (0.072 g, 0.3 mmol) and H3bidc (0.062 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (8 mL) and stirred for about 1 h at room temperature. The resulting solution was sealed in a stainless steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure, then slowly cooled to room temperature. The resulting lime green crystals were washed with water and acetonitrile to give complex 1 (62 mg, 87% yield based on Cu). Crystals suitable for structural analysis were collected and dried in air. Found: C, 32.8; H, 3.4; N, 8.5. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C9H11CuN2O7.5: C, 32.7; H, 3.4; N 8.5. Preparation of [Cu(Hbidc)]n (2)

Complex 2 was prepared by the same procedure for 1 except that the reaction temperature was 160 °C. For 2, C9H4CuN2O4, 46 mg, yield: 53% (based on Cu). Found: C, 40.5; H, 1.6; N, 10.5. Anal. Calcd. (%): C, 40.4; H, 1.5; N 10.5. IR (KBr, pellet/cm-1): 3,345, 3,142, 1,637, 1,549, 1,477, 1,415, 1,307, 1,252, 1,184, 1,039, 966, 886, 797, 635.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on both complexes in air, with heating to 780 °C at a rate of 1 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different thermal behaviors, but the TG curve of 2 is similar to that of 1 (from 228 to 780 °C, Fig. 3). In 1, the TGA displays two obvious steps of weight loss. The first corresponds to the loss of both lattice and coordinated water (at the range of 85–264 °C, the weight loss observed is 19.16%; theoretical 19.04%). The second weight loss above 250 °C is attributable to decomposition of the organic ligand. The TGA of compound 2 demonstrates that compound 2 has an excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 250 °C.

The magnetic behaviors of complexes 1 and 2 are illustrated in Fig. 4 in the form of μeff versus T plots. At 300 K, the value of μeff is 1.72 μB for compound 1, which is as expected for the spin-only value of 1.73 μB for one Cu(II) atom. Upon cooling, this value remains constant before rapidly decreasing at low temperature. This magnetic behavior reveals a weak antiferromagnetic interaction as expected. In 1, large Cu···Cu distances of and absence of effective overlap make the possible interactions weak [15, 16]. For complex 2, the value of μeff at 300 K is 2.2 μB per two Cu(II) atoms which is slightly less than that of two non-interacting Cu(II) atoms. The value gradually rises as the temperature decreases, to reach 2.91 μB at around 20 K. This behavior is typical of ferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) dinuclear compounds [14, 17, 18]. Below that temperature, μeff decreases to 2.56 μB at about 3 K, which may originate from intermolecular antiferromagnetic interactions or from zero-field splitting of the S = 1 state of the dinuclear species. This overall ferromagnetic behavior has been observed earlier for many other oxo-bridged compounds. For Cu–O–Cu dinuclear compounds, a ferromagnetic interaction was found when the Cu–O–Cu angle was smaller than 97.5°, but when the angle is larger than 97.5°, an antiferromagnetic interaction would be expected [19]. In compound 2, the Cu–O–Cu is 80.12(1)° (Cu···Cu 2.821(8) Å), which suggests the presence of ferromagnetic interactions involving the dimeric units.
